paragraphs.context: The Victoria and Albert Museum traces its roots back to the Great Exhibition of 1851, an event in which Henry Cole, the museum's inaugural director, played a key role in planning. Initially known as the Museum of Manufactures, it was first established in May 1852 at Marlborough House, but later relocated to Somerset House by September of the same year. During its early years, the museum's collections encompassed both applied art and science, with many exhibits from the Great Exhibition being acquired to form its core. In February 1854, discussions began to transfer the museum to its present location and it was subsequently renamed the South Kensington Museum. In 1855, at Cole's request, the German architect Gottfried Semper presented a design for the museum, but it was ultimately rejected by the Board of Trade due to its high cost. The museum initially occupied Brompton Park House, which was later expanded to include the first refreshment rooms in 1857, making it the first museum in the world to offer such amenities.

paragraphs.context:
As the Museum Curator, I take pride in the fact that on 22 June 1857, Queen Victoria herself officially opened our museum. To better cater to the working classes, we introduced late night openings the following year, thanks to the convenience of gas lighting. Our goal was to determine the most suitable hours for the working class, as we believed that our collections of applied art and science could serve as valuable educational resources to boost productive industry.

During the early years, we placed a strong emphasis on the practical use of our collection, distancing ourselves from the focus on "High Art" at the National Gallery and scholarly pursuits at the British Museum. Our first Keeper of Fine Art Collection, George Wallis, fervently advocated for widespread art education through our museum's collections. This led to the transfer of the School of Design, founded in 1837 at Somerset House, to our museum. It became known as the Art School or Art Training School, eventually evolving into the esteemed Royal College of Art, which achieved full independence in 1949.

Between the 1860s and the 1880s, we relocated our scientific collections from the main museum site to makeshift galleries located west of Exhibition Road. It was in 1893 that the "Science Museum" truly came into existence, with the appointment of a dedicated director.

paragraphs.context: The historical buildings of the museum have a rich and complex past, with various architects adding their own unique touches over time. The museum was established in May 1852, but it wasn't until 1857 that it found its current location in what was then known as Brompton, later renamed South Kensington. The land originally housed Brompton Park House, which was expanded with the addition of the "Brompton Boilers" – utilitarian iron galleries that had a temporary appearance and were eventually repurposed to construct the V&A Museum of Childhood. The first permanent structure to be built within the museum complex was the Sheepshanks Gallery in 1857, situated on the eastern side of the garden. Captain Francis Fowke, a civil engineer from the Royal Engineers, was the architect responsible for this gallery, having been appointed by Cole. Subsequent expansions, such as the Turner and Vernon galleries erected in 1858-9 to house specific collections (later transferred to the Tate Gallery), were also designed by Fowke. These galleries now serve as the picture and tapestry galleries respectively. The North and South Courts were constructed shortly after and were both open to the public by June 1862. Currently, these areas house temporary exhibitions and are located directly behind the Sheepshanks Gallery. The Secretariat Wing can be found at the northernmost part of the site and was also built in 1862. This section is not accessible to the public and is primarily used for housing the offices and board room, among other facilities.

paragraphs.context: In order to enhance the beauty of the new areas, a captivating plan was devised to adorn them with mosaic figures portraying renowned European artists from the Medieval and Renaissance era. These magnificent artworks have since been relocated to different parts of the museum. Additionally, Lord Leighton commenced the creation of a series of frescoes titled "Industrial Arts as Applied to War 1878-1880" and "Industrial Arts Applied to Peace," although the latter remained unfinished. Adjacent to these galleries, the Oriental Courts were constructed, showcasing fascinating decorations inspired by India, China, and Japan. Unfortunately, none of these splendid adornments have survived, but several of the galleries were later transformed to exhibit the wonders of the 19th century, which were unveiled in December 2006. Amongst the final contributions of Fowke was the design for the buildings encircling the garden's north and west sides. Notably, the Museum Café, restored in 2006, occupies the ground floor, while the silver gallery, which formerly housed ceramics, is situated above. A remarkable lecture theatre also graces the top floor, though it is rarely accessible to the general public. The ceramic staircase positioned in the northwest corner of this building range was conceptualized by F. W. Moody and showcases intricate architectural details crafted from molded and colored pottery. The entirety of the north range was constructed between the years 1864 and 1869, with an emphasis on the magnificent style of the Italian Renaissance. Terracotta, brick, and mosaic were extensively employed, infusing grandeur into the north façade which was intended to serve as the primary entrance to the museum. Immaculately designed bronze doors, skillfully crafted by James Gamble & Reuben Townroe, feature six panels depicting a diverse range of prominent figures, including Humphry Davy (chemistry), Isaac Newton (astronomy), James Watt (mechanics), Bramante (architecture), Michelangelo (sculpture), and Titian (painting). These panels serve as a true representation of the museum's rich collections. Godfrey Sykes, in conjunction with Percival Ball, contributed to the overall splendor by adding terracotta embellishments and a mosaic in the pediment of the North Façade, commemorating the Great Exhibition. The profits from this exhibition played a vital role in financing the museum. This remarkable building took the place of Brompton Park House, which was subsequently demolished to pave the way for the south range.

paragraphs.context: When I visited the museum, I noticed that the refreshment rooms were each designed by different talented artists. The Green Dining Room, created by Philip Webb and William Morris, had a charming Elizabethan influence. The walls were adorned with wooden panels featuring beautiful paintings of fruit and occasional figures. Edward Burne-Jones' stained-glass windows and plaster foliage added an elegant touch to the room. Moving on to the Centre Refreshment Room, I was amazed by the Renaissance style designed by James Gamble. The walls and even the Ionic columns were covered in decorative ceramic tiles, while the ceiling showcased elaborate designs on metal sheets. The marble fireplace, sculpted by Alfred Stevens, had been carefully taken from Dorchester House. Lastly, the Grill Room, designed by Sir Edward Poynter, had a lovely blue and white tile decoration. The walls depicted various figures and foliage, and above them were large scenes representing the four seasons and the twelve months, painted by talented ladies from the Art School situated in the museum. The presence of stained glass windows and an elaborate cast-iron grill completed the charming ambiance of the room.

paragraphs.context: Following the passing of Captain Francis Fowke, a renowned architect, the responsibility of designing the next addition to the museum fell upon Colonel (later Major General) Henry Young Darracott Scott, who also hailed from the distinguished Royal Engineers. In the year 1867 to 1872, he created the School for Naval Architects, commonly referred to as the science schools, situated in the northwest section of the garden. One of the standout features of this architectural marvel is the magnificent staircase crafted by Scott's assistant, J.W. Wild. Constructed using Cadeby stone, the steps are an impressive 7 feet (2.1 m) in length, while the balustrades and columns are fashioned from Portland stone. Presently, this wing of the museum serves as a shared space for housing the prints and architectural drawings of the V&A (prints, drawings, paintings, and photographs) and the Royal Institute of British Architects (RIBA Drawings and Archives Collections). Additionally, it accommodates the Sackler Centre, an arts education facility that was inaugurated in 2008.

answers.text: Colonel (later Major General) Henry Young Darracott Scott,
Colonel (later Major General) Henry Young Darracott Scott

paragraphs.context: In accordance with the architectural style prevalent at the time, a team of designers undertook the task of adorning the building. The terracotta embellishments were skillfully crafted by Godfrey Sykes, while sgraffito technique was employed to ornament the eastern side of the structure, which was designed by F. W. Moody. Additionally, a noteworthy feature was the wrought iron gates, designed by Starkie Gardner as late as 1885, which provided access to a passage within the building. Another remarkable addition to the museum, known as the Cast Courts, was designed by Scott himself between 1870 and 1873. These expansive spaces, situated southeast of the garden on the site of the "Brompton Boilers," boast ceilings reaching a staggering height of 70 feet (21 m). Their purpose was to house plaster casts of renowned architectural elements, including the iconic Trajan's Column, which was divided into two separate pieces. Complementing this, Scott's architectural vision extended further to include the construction of the Art Library and what now serves as the sculpture gallery on the south side of the garden. This particular section, built from 1877 to 1883, featured mosaic panels on its exterior parapet, thoughtfully designed by Reuben Townroe. Townroe also lent his artistic expertise to the plaster work within the library. Notably, Sir John Taylor was responsible for the design of the bookshelves and cases, and this area was the first part of the museum to be illuminated by electric lighting. With the completion of these developments, the northern half of the museum's site took shape as a quadrangle, with the garden at its heart. However, the lack of a proper façade prompted the government to initiate a competition in 1890 for the design of new museum buildings, which ultimately led to the creation of a grand and imposing front entrance, overseen by architect Alfred Waterhouse.

paragraphs.context: The front-facing side of the museum, stretching 720 feet along Cromwell Gardens, showcases an interesting blend of architectural styles. Designed by Aston Webb, the façade combines elements of Renaissance and medieval influences. The main entrance, featuring shallow arches supported by slender columns and niches with twin doors, has a Romanesque form with Classical details. The tower above the entrance displays a unique open work crown topped by a statue of fame, a feature commonly found in late Gothic architecture in Scotland, but incorporating Classical details. The galleries' main windows also follow a Gothic style with mullioned and transomed designs, with the top row of windows adorned with statues of renowned British artists whose artwork is exhibited in the museum.

paragraphs.context:
In the years following the war, there was limited funding available for anything beyond necessary repairs. From the 1950s to the early 1960s, there was little construction happening. However, in 1966 and 1967, the Art Library decided to create additional storage space for books. They transformed Aston Webb's main hall into book stacks and added a new medieval gallery on the ground floor, which is now the shop that opened in 2006. The museum also underwent renovations to the lower ground-floor galleries in the southwest area, which were completed in 1978. These new galleries showcased Continental art from 1600 to 1800, including late Renaissance, Baroque, Rococo, and neo-Classical pieces.

In 1974, the museum acquired the Henry Cole wing from the Royal College of Science. To turn it into galleries, they remodeled the Victorian interiors, except for the staircase. In order to connect this new wing to the rest of the museum, they constructed a new entrance building on the site where the former boiler house stood, which was originally planned as the location for the Spiral. This functional concrete building includes a notable embellishment, the iron gates created by Christopher Hay and Douglas Coyne from the Royal College of Art. These gates are set within the columned screen wall designed by Aston Webb, forming the façade of the entrance building.

paragraphs.context:
In the 1990s, we decided to redesign a few galleries at our museum, including the Indian, Japanese, Chinese, ironwork, the main glass galleries, and the main silverware gallery. In 2002, we further enhanced the main silverware gallery by recreating some of its Victorian decoration. As part of the 2006 renovation, we also restored the mosaic floors in the sculpture gallery, as most of the Victorian floors had been covered in linoleum after the Second World War.

After the successful opening of the British Galleries in 2001, we made the decision to embark on a major redesign of all the galleries in the museum. This initiative, called "FuturePlan", was developed in consultation with exhibition designers and masterplanners Metaphor. Our plan, which started in 2002, is expected to take about ten years to complete.

To date, we have redesigned several galleries as part of FuturePlan. In 2002, we redesigned the main silverware gallery and the contemporary gallery. In 2003, we redesigned the Photography gallery, the main entrance, and the Painting Galleries. In 2004, we redesigned various areas, including the tunnel to the subway leading to South Kensington tube station, and the V&A and RIBA reading rooms and stores. We also redesigned the Members' Room, the contemporary glass gallery, and the Gilbert Bayes sculpture gallery. In 2005, we tackled the portrait miniatures, prints and drawings, displays in Room 117, the garden, sacred silver, and stained glass. Finally, in 2006, we redesigned the Central Hall Shop, the Islamic Middle East gallery, the new café, and the sculpture galleries.

Throughout this redesign process, we have collaborated with various talented designers and architects. For example, Eva Jiřičná was responsible for enhancing the main entrance, rotunda, new shop, tunnel, and sculpture galleries. Gareth Hoskins took charge of the contemporary and architecture galleries, the Softroom team handled the Islamic Middle East gallery and the Members' Room, and McInnes Usher McKnight Architects (MUMA) designed the new café and the Medieval and Renaissance galleries that opened in 2009.

answers.text: the mosaic floors in the sculpture gallery

qas.question: What was restored in the sculpture gallery during its renovated in 2006?

paragraphs.context: The renowned landscape architect Kim Wilkie was commissioned to redesign the central garden, which now bears the name of John Madejski Garden, and was officially unveiled on 5th July 2005. The garden's design seamlessly melds together both classic and contemporary elements. Its layout features an elegant elliptical water feature made of stone, encircled by steps. Interestingly, this water feature can be purposefully emptied to provide a versatile space, perfect for hosting receptions, gatherings, or exhibitions. Positioned in front of the garden's bronze doors, which lead to the refreshment rooms, a central walkway bordered by lush lawns leads visitors to the sculpture gallery. Along the museum's walls on the north, east, and west sides, beautifully designed herbaceous borders grace the paths, which continue along the south-facing facade. As an added touch, at the two corners by the garden's north-facing exterior, an American Sweetgum tree stands as a testament to nature's grandeur. On the lawns' southern, eastern, and western edges, glass planters showcase the vibrant presence of orange and lemon trees during the summer months, while being replaced by bay trees during the winter season.

paragraphs.context: In 2004, the V&A, in collaboration with the Royal Institute of British Architects, inaugurated the inaugural permanent exhibition in the United Kingdom dedicated to the evolutionary journey of architecture. The gallery showcases an array of models, photographs, fragments from significant architectural landmarks, and original drawings. This momentous occasion also marked the integration of the RIBA Drawings and Archives Collection into the museum's already extensive assortment. With a staggering collection of over 600,000 drawings, 750,000 papers, and related artifacts, as well as more than 700,000 photographs originating from various corners of the world, this combined compilation represents the most comprehensive architectural resource available globally.

With over 330 drawings, the RIBA holds the largest collection of Andrea Palladio's works in the world. The European section of the collection includes works by Jacques Gentilhatre and Antonio Visentini. Not to be overlooked are the drawings and, in some cases, models of renowned British architects such as Inigo Jones, Sir Christopher Wren, Sir John Vanbrugh, Nicholas Hawksmoor, William Kent, James Gibbs, Robert Adam, Sir William Chambers, James Wyatt, Henry Holland, John Nash, Sir John Soane, Sir Charles Barry, Charles Robert Cockerell, Augustus Welby Northmore Pugin, Sir George Gilbert Scott, John Loughborough Pearson, George Edmund Street, Richard Norman Shaw, Alfred Waterhouse, Sir Edwin Lutyens, Charles Rennie Mackintosh, Charles Holden, Frank Hoar, Lord Richard Rogers, Lord Norman Foster, Sir Nicholas Grimshaw, Zaha Hadid, and Alick Horsnell.

paragraphs.context: In addition to the period rooms, our museum collection showcases fragments of iconic buildings. For instance, we proudly exhibit the ornately carved woodwork and leaded windows from the top two stories of Sir Paul Pindar's house, which dates back to c1600 and survived the devastating Great Fire of London. We also have a remarkable brick portal from a London house during the English Restoration period and a fireplace from the gallery of Northumberland House. Among our European artifacts, visitors can marvel at a dormer window from the chateau of Montal, dating from 1523-35. Our Italian Renaissance section offers portals, fireplaces, balconies, and even a stone buffet with a previously integrated fountain. To highlight the diversity of architectural styles, our main gallery proudly showcases pillars from various buildings and periods, including a column from the Alhambra. We encourage visitors with an interest in Asian architecture to explore our specialized galleries, which feature examples, models, and photographs from those specific countries.

paragraphs.context: The Victoria and Albert Museum presents an extensive collection of over 19,000 items from the Islamic world, spanning from the 7th century to the early 20th century. One of the main attractions within the museum is the Jameel Gallery of Islamic Art, which was established in 2006. This gallery showcases a diverse array of 400 objects, prominently featuring the magnificent Ardabil Carpet as its centerpiece. Visitors can explore the rich cultural heritage of regions such as Spain, North Africa, the Middle East, Central Asia, and Afghanistan through these displays. Noteworthy pieces include a captivating 10th-century Rock crystal ewer, beautifully calligraphed Qur'āns from various eras, and a large 15th-century minbar adorned with intricate ivory patterns, originating from a mosque in Cairo. Furthermore, visitors can admire the museum's exceptional collection of ceramics, including exquisite Iznik pottery, as well as 14th-century mosque lamps and metalwork. Renowned for its Middle Eastern and Persian rugs and carpets, the museum houses some of the world's finest examples, some of which were acquired through the Salting Bequest of 1909. Other captivating exhibits include tile work, such as a stunningly decorated blue and white fireplace from Istanbul dating back to 1731, and turquoise tiles sourced from buildings in Samarkand.

qas.question: Approximately how many items from the Islamic world are held in the V&A collection?
In which year did the Jameel Gallery of Islamic Art opened?
In which year was the Salting Bequest?

paragraphs.context: The museum I work at houses the most extensive and significant collections of South and South-East Asian art in the West. We have a diverse range of about 60,000 objects, including 10,000 textiles and 6,000 paintings. One of our remarkable galleries, called the Jawaharlal Nehru gallery of Indian art, was established in 1991. It showcases art from around 500 BC to the 19th century. The focus of this gallery is mainly on religious sculpture, representing Hindu, Buddhist, and Jain traditions. We are proud to have exquisite art pieces from the Mughal Empire and the Marathas, featuring stunning portraits of emperors, paintings, drawings, jade wine cups, and gold spoons adorned with emeralds, diamonds, and rubies. Additionally, parts of historical buildings such as a jaali and pillars are on display. Our museum also highlights India's contribution to the textile industry. We exhibit dyed cotton chintz, muslin, and beautifully embroidered textiles using gold and silver thread, sequins, and beads. Visitors can also admire carpets from Agra and Lahore, along with a collection of traditional clothing.

paragraphs.context: The V&A Museum houses an extensive collection of over 70,000 artistic works from East Asia, specifically China, Japan, and Korea. In 1991, the T. T. Tsui Gallery of Chinese art was established to exhibit a representative selection of the museum's impressive collection of approximately 16,000 Chinese objects spanning from the 4th millennium BC to the present day. While the majority of items on display date back to the Ming and Qing dynasties, the gallery also showcases remarkable artifacts from earlier periods, including a magnificent bronze Buddha head dating back to around 750 AD and a 2,000-year-old jade horse head discovered in a burial site. Additionally, visitors can admire life-size tomb guardians, exquisite examples of Chinese manufacturing such as lacquer, silk, porcelain, jade, and cloisonné enamel. The gallery also features a pair of watercolor portrait paintings from the 18th century depicting a husband and wife, a unique lacquerware table crafted during the Ming dynasty, and a variety of clothing items. A notable exhibit is a mid-17th century bed, one of the largest objects on display. To incorporate contemporary art, the gallery also showcases the creativity of Chinese designers. The T. T. Tsui Gallery of Chinese art at the V&A Museum offers visitors a comprehensive and captivating exploration of the art and culture of China, enriching their museum experience.

answers.text: T. T. Tsui Gallery of Chinese art
The T. T. Tsui Gallery of Chinese art

paragraphs.context: The Toshiba gallery of Japanese art first opened its doors to the public in December of 1986. This esteemed gallery focuses on showcasing a captivating collection primarily dating from 1550 to 1900. However, one of the most treasured and ancient sculptures on display is a breathtaking 13th-century depiction of Amida Nyorai. As visitors meander through the gallery, they will be treated to an extraordinary array of artifacts and artworks. These include splendid examples of traditional Japanese armor crafted during the mid-19th century, exquisite blades of steel known as Katana, intricate Inrō, and delicate lacquerware such as the renowned Mazarin Chest from around 1640, which is regarded as a masterpiece originating from Kyoto. Additionally, visitors will feast their eyes upon captivating porcelain pieces including Imari, intricate Netsuke carvings, captivating woodblock prints featuring the immortal creations of Ando Hiroshige, and graphic works that include beautifully printed books as well as a selection of rare paintings, scrolls, and screens. The museum also boasts an impressive collection of textiles and dresses, most notably the elegant kimonos. Amongst these marvels, one of the true gems of the gallery is the magnificent bronze incense burner (koro) artfully crafted by Suzuki Chokichi in 1875. This awe-inspiring work of art stands at a remarkable height of over 2.25 meters with a diameter of 1.25 meters, making it one of the largest examples of its kind. Additionally, the museum proudly showcases striking cloisonné pieces originating from the esteemed Japanese art production company known as Ando Cloisonné.

paragraphs.context:
As a curator at the museum, it is my responsibility to display a diverse range of art from different regions and time periods. In our smaller galleries, we have a section dedicated to the art of Korea, the Himalayan kingdoms, and Southeast Asia. The Korean displays showcase various artifacts such as green-glazed ceramics, silk embroideries from officials' robes, and exquisite boxes adorned with mother-of-pearl. These items were crafted between 500 AD and 2000, showcasing the artistic prowess of the region across centuries.

Moving on to the Himalayan section, we have a collection of significant early Nepalese bronze sculptures, repoussé work, and stunning embroidery. The art from Tibetan culture, spanning from the 14th to the 19th century, is also showcased prominently in our galleries. Notable religious images in wood and bronze from the 14th and 15th centuries, along with scroll paintings and ritual objects, offer a glimpse into the spiritual and artistic aspects of Tibetan traditions.

Additionally, we have a fantastic range of art from Thailand, Burma, Cambodia, Indonesia, and Sri Lanka. These pieces, crafted in gold, silver, bronze, stone, terracotta, and ivory, represent the rich and complex cultures of these regions. They cover a wide time frame, spanning from the 6th to the 19th centuries. Among the highlights are refined Hindu and Buddhist sculptures, which beautifully reflect the influence of India. The collection includes exquisite betel-nut cutters, ivory combs, and bronze palanquin hooks, showcasing the intricate craftsmanship of the artisans from these regions.

paragraphs.context: One of the most prized possessions in our library is the Codex Forster, a collection of Leonardo da Vinci's personal notebooks. The Codex consists of three small manuscripts, known as Forster I, Forster II, and Forster III, which were created between 1490 and 1505. Inside these manuscripts, you can find a wealth of sketches and references related to the equestrian sculpture project commissioned by Ludovico Sforza, the Duke of Milan, to honor his father Francesco Sforza. These valuable manuscripts were generously donated to our museum in 1876 by John Forster, along with a remarkable collection of over 18,000 books. Additionally, our library was enriched in 1869 when Reverend Alexander Dyce, another generous benefactor, bequeathed an impressive collection of over 14,000 books. Among these treasures, you can find early Greek and Latin editions of renowned poets and playwrights such as Aeschylus, Aristotle, Homer, Livy, Ovid, Pindar, Sophocles, and Virgil. We are also fortunate to possess works by more recent authors like Giovanni Boccaccio, Dante, Racine, Rabelais, and Molière.

qas.question: The Codex Forster is a collection of notebooks by which famous Italian Renaissance polymath?

answers.text: Forster I, Forster II, and Forster III

Forster I, Forster II, and Forster III

paragraphs.context: In our Word and Image Department at the National Art Library, we have various formats of collection catalogs including printed exhibit catalogs and card catalogs. Back in the 1980s and 1990s, we used the MODES cataloging system, but unfortunately, the electronic files were not accessible to our library users. However, we have made significant progress in organizing our archival material using the Encoded Archival Description (EAD) system. Although the majority of items in our collection, unless newly accessioned, may not be reflected in our computer system at the Victoria and Albert Museum, you can still utilize the "Search the Collections" feature on our website. Please keep in mind that not all items are listed there, but we are continuously working to expand the database.

paragraphs.context:
As an Archival Specialist at the Victoria and Albert Museum, I have been immersed in the ongoing digitization efforts of the Word and Image Department since 2007. Our ambitious Factory Project, aptly named in reference to Andy Warhol's innovative approach, aims to meticulously digitize and catalog the entire collection. To kickstart the process, we utilized digital cameras to capture high-quality photographs of the items. This allowed us to enhance accessibility for researchers by making the new photographs available on the museum's website.

During the inaugural year of the Factory Project, we successfully captured a staggering 15,000 images, encompassing a diverse range of art forms such as drawings, watercolors, computer-generated art, photographs, posters, and woodcuts. Building upon this progress, the next step is to diligently catalog each item, ensuring a comprehensive database that facilitates efficient retrieval of information.

To maintain an accurate record, the Factory Project also incorporates an essential auditing phase. We meticulously cross-reference the items we have photographed and cataloged with their physical existence within the collection. This crucial step ensures that all listed items were physically accounted for during the project's implementation.

Furthermore, our commitment to conservation is a paramount goal of the Factory Project. We perform necessary preventive procedures to safeguard the integrity of the collection, ensuring its longevity for future generations to appreciate and study.

Users of the Victoria and Albert Museum website benefit greatly from our large-scale digitization endeavors. The inclusion of a user-friendly "Search the Collections" feature allows visitors to explore numerous items within our comprehensive computer databases.

Ultimately, the Factory Project evolved as a response to the widespread need to expand and document the collections through digitization. By harnessing cutting-edge technology and drawing inspiration from Andy Warhol's innovative legacy, we strive to capture, preserve, and share the rich artistic heritage housed within the Victoria and Albert Museum.

qas.question: In which year did the V&A's Word and Image Department began a large scale digitization project?
What was the digitization project called?
The title of the digitization project was a reference to which artist?
Approximately how many images were digitized during the first year of the digitization project?

paragraphs.context: As we explore the galleries, we can observe how design in different periods of British culture was influenced by various factors. For instance, during the Tudor period, the spread of printed books and the presence of European artists and craftsmen working in Britain greatly impacted design. Moving into the Stuart period, increased trade, particularly with Asia, allowed for wider availability of luxurious items such as carpets, lacquered furniture, silks, and porcelain. In the Georgian age, there was a growing focus on entertainment and leisure, as evidenced by the rising popularity of tea drinking and the subsequent production of tea-related items like china and caddies. The influence of European styles, discovered through the Grand Tour, also played a significant role in shaping taste during this era. The Industrial Revolution brought about mass production, leading to the emergence of notable entrepreneurs such as Josiah Wedgwood, Matthew Boulton, and Eleanor Coade. In the Victorian era, advancements in technology and machinery greatly impacted manufacturing, and we also witnessed the Anglican and Roman Catholic Churches exerting a strong influence on art and design, as seen in the Gothic Revival movement. The grand display on the Great Exhibition, which played a pivotal role in the establishment of the V&A, is also showcased in the galleries. Finally, in the later 19th century, we see the Arts and Crafts movement gaining momentum as a response to the increasing backlash against industrialization, largely propelled by the influential figure of John Ruskin.

paragraphs.context: As a museum curator, I take pride in showcasing the most captivating exhibits in our sculpture wing. One of the highlights is the Cast Courts, which consists of two spacious rooms with large skylights, reaching up to two storeys high. These rooms house an extensive collection of plaster casts, including sculptures, friezes, and tombs. In one room, we have an awe-inspiring replica of Trajan's Column, which had to be cut in half to fit within the ceiling's limits. The other room features reproductions of various iconic Italian Renaissance sculptures and architectural structures, such as a life-size replica of Michelangelo's David. Additionally, we proudly display replicas of two earlier versions of David by Donatello and Verrocchio. However, to ensure the conservation of the delicate Verrocchio replica, it is securely exhibited in a glass case.

paragraphs.context: Within our remarkable collection, we take great pride in showcasing Meissen porcelain, which originated from Europe's first porcelain factory that adopted the Chinese porcelain-making technique. Of particular note are the exquisite Meissen Vulture created in 1731 and the Möllendorff Dinner Service, a brilliant design by Frederick II the Great from 1762. We have an extensive array of ceramics from the Manufacture nationale de Sèvres, spanning the 18th and 19th centuries. Our collection of 18th-century British porcelain stands unrivaled in terms of both size and quality. We have remarkable examples from every factory, with exceptional pieces from Chelsea porcelain and Worcester Porcelain. Additionally, we have comprehensive representation from all significant British porcelain factories of the 19th century. An exceptional boon to our collection was the Salting Bequest in 1909, which significantly enriched our holdings of Chinese and Japanese ceramics. Consequently, our museum boasts one of the world's most exceptional collections of East Asian pottery and porcelain, including the renowned Kakiemon ware.

paragraphs.context: The glass collection in the museum showcases a diverse range of glass items from different parts of the world and various time periods. Spanning over 4000 years, it highlights the evolution of glass making from Ancient Egypt to the Ancient Roman period, followed by the Medieval and Renaissance eras. Notable glass styles, such as Venetian glass and Bohemian glass, are also featured. Moving forward in time, the collection includes magnificent Art Nouveau glass creations by renowned artists like Louis Comfort Tiffany and Émile Gallé. The influence of the Art Deco style is evident through the exquisite pieces crafted by René Lalique. Among the collection, visitors can admire stunning crystal chandeliers, including English ones showcased in the British galleries, and others like the Venetian chandelier attributed to Giuseppe Briati from around 1750. In terms of stained glass, the museum boasts one of the world's finest collections, encompassing medieval to modern periods and displaying works both from Europe and Britain. Notable stained glass designers like Dante Gabriel Rossetti, Edward Burne-Jones, and William Morris from the 19th century are well-represented. Additionally, visitors can appreciate the masterpiece created by Frank Lloyd Wright. The collection also showcases the creative works of 20th-century designers like Harry Clarke, John Piper, Patrick Reyntiens, Veronica Whall, and Brian Clarke.

paragraphs.context: The museum obtained the Soulages collection of Italian and French Renaissance objects during the period between 1859 and 1865. This remarkable collection includes various cassone. Additionally, in 1882, the esteemed John Jones Collection of French 18th-century art and furnishings, valued at £250,000 during that time, was generously gifted to the museum. Among the significant pieces within this collection is a marquetry commode crafted by the talented ébéniste Jean Henri Riesener, dating back to approximately 1780. Furthermore, the collection proudly showcases other exquisite, signed furniture pieces such as a bureau by Jean-François Oeben, a pair of pedestals with inlaid brass work by André Charles Boulle, a commode by Bernard Vanrisamburgh, and a work-table by Martin Carlin. The Museum's collection also encompasses the works of several renowned 18th-century ébénistes, including Adam Weisweiler, David Roentgen, Gilles Joubert, and Pierre Langlois. Notably, in 1901, Sir George Donaldson kindly donated a number of art Nouveau furniture pieces to the museum, which he had acquired the previous year at the Paris Exposition Universelle. However, this act faced criticism at the time, resulting in the museum refraining from collecting contemporary items until the 1960s. Ultimately, in 1986, the museum was honored to receive the Lady Abingdon collection of French Empire furniture as a bequest from Mrs. T. R. P. Hole.

paragraphs.context: As a museum curator, I am proud to oversee a remarkable jewellery collection that features over 6000 exquisite pieces. This collection is renowned for its comprehensive representation of jewellery throughout history, from the ancient times of Egypt to the present day. We are fortunate to possess stunning works from esteemed jewellers like Cartier, Jean Schlumberger, Peter Carl Fabergé, Hemmerle, and Lalique. Notable items in our collection include dazzling diamond dress ornaments created for the esteemed Catherine the Great, precious bracelet clasps that once belonged to the iconic Marie Antoinette, and the stunning Beauharnais emerald necklace that Napoleon presented to his cherished adopted daughter, Hortense de Beauharnais, in 1806. Alongside these treasures, we also take pride in the inclusion of international modern jewellery by esteemed designers such as Gijs Bakker, Onno Boekhoudt, Peter Chang, Gerda Flockinger, Lucy Sarneel, Dorothea Prühl, and Wendy Ramshaw, as well as an impressive assortment of African and Asian traditional jewellery. Our collection has been enriched through the generosity of various individuals and their significant contributions, including Reverend Chauncy Hare Townshend's remarkable collection of 154 gems bequeathed in 1869, Lady Cory's remarkable gift of major diamond jewellery from the 18th and 19th centuries in 1951, and the esteemed jewellery scholar Dame Joan Evans' donation of over 800 jewels from the Middle Ages to the early 19th century in 1977. Thanks to the generous support of William and Judith Bollinger, we were able to inaugurate a state-of-the-art jewellery gallery on May 24, 2008.

paragraphs.context: In our collection, we have a remarkable assortment of more than 10,000 precious objects crafted from silver or gold. When displaying these exquisite pieces (which make up around 15% of our collection), we have divided them into two categories: secular and sacred. These categories encompass various Christian denominations (such as Roman Catholic, Anglican, and Greek Orthodox) as well as Jewish liturgical vessels and items. To provide a well-organized exhibition, our main silver gallery is further divided into specific sections, including British silver pre-1800, British silver 1800 to 1900, modernist to contemporary silver, and European silver. Among the treasures in our collection, we are fortunate to possess the oldest known English silver piece with a dated hallmark, namely a silver gilt beaker that dates back to 1496–97. Furthermore, we proudly exhibit the works of renowned silversmiths, including Paul de Lamerie and Paul Storr. As a highlight, Storr's remarkable Castlereagh Inkstand, crafted between 1817 and 1819, stands as one of his finest creations. Additionally, our museum features a comprehensive ironwork gallery that showcases European wrought and cast iron from the medieval period to the early 20th century. Here, visitors can explore the masterful craftsmanship of Jean Tijou, with examples of his intricate ironwork and designs on paper. Notably, one of the largest items in our collection is the Hereford Screen, an awe-inspiring structure weighing nearly 8 tonnes, measuring 10.5 meters in height and 11 meters in width. Originally designed by the esteemed Sir George Gilbert Scott in 1862 for the chancel in Hereford Cathedral, it was later relocated in 1967. Skidmore & Company brought this grand vision to life, constructing the screen using a combination of timber, cast iron, wrought iron, burnished brass, and copper. The artistic elements of the screen, including the arches, columns, and panels, are adorned with polished quartz and mosaic, showcasing an extensive palette of vibrant colors.

paragraphs.context: In our collection, we are fortunate to have the incredibly rare Gloucester Candlestick, which dates back to around 1110. This exquisite piece, crafted from gilt bronze, showcases the remarkable skill of the bronze casters with its intricate branches adorned with small figures and inscriptions. It truly is a masterpiece. Another significant item is the Becket Casket, dating back to around 1180. This stunning relic, made from gilt copper, contains important remnants of St Thomas Becket and features beautifully enameled scenes depicting his martyrdom. Lastly, there's the remarkable 1351 Reichenau Crozier. However, our real showstopper is the Burghley Nef - a French salt-cellar from 1527-28. It's crafted with great artistry, utilizing a nautilus shell to form the vessel's hull. Sitting atop the tail of a parcel-gilt mermaid, it rests on a hexagonal gilt plinth supported by six claw-and-ball feet. The masts boast impressive sail arrangements, and the gold battlemented fighting-tops add an extra touch of grandeur. These extraordinary artifacts are displayed in our recently opened Medieval & Renaissance galleries.

paragraphs.context: The closure of the Musical Instruments gallery on 25 February 2010 sparked significant controversy among museum visitors and enthusiasts. paragraphs.context:
As a museum conservation specialist at the V&A and the V&A Museum of Childhood, my primary responsibility is the long-term preservation of the collections. I have specialized knowledge in specific areas of conservation. One aspect of my work is focused on "preventive" conservation. This involves conducting surveys, assessments, and providing professional advice on how to handle items properly. I ensure that objects are correctly packaged, mounted, and handled during their movement and display to minimize the risk of damage. Additionally, I am responsible for controlling the museum environment, including monitoring and regulating temperature and light to protect the integrity of the artifacts. Another crucial component of my work is preventing pests, primarily insects, from causing damage to the valuable objects.

I also engage in "interventive" conservation, which includes meticulously cleaning and restoring fragile objects to strengthen them and reveal their original surface decoration. This process not only enhances the stability of the objects but also makes them more visually appealing and understandable to the museum visitors. Interventive treatment is typically undertaken on items that are intended to be displayed publicly. Through my expertise and intervention, I ensure that these treasured artifacts are not only preserved but also presented in the best possible condition, engaging and captivating viewers.

qas.question: What two environmental conditions are controlled in the museum?

paragraphs.context: Capital Cities Communications, a media conglomerate, was originally launched as a radio network on October 12, 1943. It was established as an independent entity after the acquisition of the NBC Blue Network by Edward J. Noble. Recognizing the potential of television, Capital Cities Communications expanded its operations to television in 1948, following the footsteps of established broadcast networks like CBS and NBC. In order to strengthen its presence in the entertainment industry, Capital Cities Communications merged with United Paramount Theatres, a subsidiary of Paramount Pictures, in the mid-1950s. Leonard Goldenson, who was previously heading the United Paramount Theatres, played a crucial role in making the newly formed television network profitable by overseeing the development and approval of several successful series. Further expanding its portfolio, in the 1980s, Capital Cities Communications acquired an 80% stake in ESPN, a prominent cable sports channel. This move not only diversified their offerings but also allowed them to tap into the growing sports broadcasting industry. The success story continued as Capital Cities Communications merged with the parent company of ABC in 1985. This parent company, also called Capital Cities Communications, owned various print publications, as well as television and radio stations. This merger further solidified the company's position as a major player in the media landscape. However, in 1996, the majority of the assets owned by Capital Cities/ABC were purchased by The Walt Disney Company, signifying a significant shift in ownership and strategy for the company.

paragraphs.context: During the 1930s, radio broadcasting in the United States was primarily controlled by three major players: the Columbia Broadcasting System (CBS), the Mutual Broadcasting System, and the National Broadcasting Company (NBC), which was under the ownership of the renowned electronics manufacturer, Radio Corporation of America (RCA). RCA possessed two radio networks, namely NBC Blue and NBC Red, each offering distinct types of programming. Launched in 1927, the NBC Blue Network served as a platform to test new programs in markets that were considered less significant compared to the major cities covered by NBC Red. Additionally, the NBC Blue Network played a crucial role in experimenting with drama series.

paragraphs.context: In the late 1930s, Mutual, one of the radio networks, expressed its concerns to the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) about the difficulties it faced in expanding its reach due to the dominating presence of NBC and CBS. The FCC, in response, initiated an investigation into the practices of radio networks in 1938 and published a comprehensive report on the state of network radio programs in 1940. This report recommended that RCA, the parent company of NBC, relinquish control of either their NBC Red Network or NBC Blue Network. During this period, the FCC observed that the NBC Red Network held the position of the primary radio network in the United States and, according to their findings, RCA utilized the NBC Blue Network as a means to eliminate any form of competition. Since the FCC did not possess direct authority over the networks themselves, they implemented a regulation preventing the issuance of licenses for radio stations affiliated with a network that already owned multiple networks providing content of public interest.

paragraphs.context: After the Federal Communications Commission rejected Mutual's appeals, RCA made the decision to sell NBC Blue in 1941. They entrusted Mark Woods with the task of finding a suitable buyer for the network. RCA officially separated the operations of NBC Red and NBC Blue on January 8, 1942, converting the NBC Blue Network into an independent subsidiary. On-air, the Blue Network would now be referred to as either "Blue" or "Blue Network". As part of the separation, NBC Red and NBC Blue divided their corporate assets accordingly. Between 1942 and 1943, Woods made an offer to sell the entire NBC Blue Network, which included leases on landlines, pending television licenses for WJZ-TV in New York City, KGO-TV in San Francisco, and WENR-TV in Chicago, as well as 60 affiliates, four operations facilities located in New York City, Chicago, Los Angeles, and Washington D.C., contracts with actors, and the well-established brand associated with the Blue Network. Investment firm Dillon, Read & Co., later acquired by the Swiss Bank Corporation in 1997, expressed interest in purchasing the network for $7.5 million. However, this offer was ultimately rejected by both Mark Woods and RCA President David Sarnoff.

paragraphs.context:
Herbert Thompson, a prominent figure in the business world, found great success as the owner of Life Savers candy, the popular drugstore chain Rexall, and the renowned New York City radio station WMCA. In 1943, Thompson made a significant investment by purchasing the network for $8 million, which also included the acquisition of three RCA stations. However, in accordance with FCC ownership regulations, Thompson had to seek the Commission's approval to proceed with the transaction. Fortunately, on October 12, 1943, the FCC authorized the purchase without any major hurdles.
Following this milestone, Thompson went on to establish the American Broadcasting System, a company he founded to acquire the Blue Network. In 1944, Thompson obtained the rights to the esteemed name "American Broadcasting Company" from George B. Storer, further solidifying his influence in the industry. The parent company of ABC, known as American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., was officially formed.
Throughout this transformative period, Thompson entrusted the role of president and CEO of ABC to a capable executive named George B. Storer. Storer skillfully led the company until December 1949 when he was promoted to the esteemed position of vice-chairman of the board. However, Storer eventually parted ways with ABC on June 30, 1951, marking the end of an era.

paragraphs.context:
As a radio network executive in the 1940s, my team at ABC wanted to compete fiercely with NBC and CBS. Sharing NBC Blue's commitment to public service, we decided to air symphony performances conducted by Paul Whiteman, stunning performances from the Metropolitan Opera, and jazz concerts as part of The Chamber Music Society of Lower Basin Street, announced proficiently by Milton Cross. We also established a reputation for our gripping dramas like Sherlock Holmes, Gang Busters, and Counterspy, as well as engaging youth-oriented programs during mid-afternoons.

To differentiate ourselves, ABC embraced the strategy of counterprogramming, where we scheduled our own shows to go head-to-head against NBC and CBS. To enhance the quality of our programs, we turned to the state-of-the-art Magnetophon tape recorder, which we imported from Nazi Germany after it was conquered. By utilizing this technology, we could pre-record our shows, giving our stars the flexibility they needed, while also attracting renowned personalities like Bing Crosby. It was a major coup for us since NBC and CBS didn't allow pre-taped shows.

paragraphs.context:
In the 1990s, ESPN network experienced a second period of international expansion, which was also reflected in the policies implemented by Disney Media Networks during the 2000s. These policies aimed at expanding the company's cable networks, such as Disney Channel and its related channels Toon Disney, Playhouse Disney, and Jetix, primarily within the United States. However, as part of a strategic shift, Disney decided to sell its 33% stake in the European sports channel Eurosport for $155 million in June 2000.

While Disney's other channels focused on the American market, ABC network was primarily broadcasted in the United States but had syndicated programming in numerous countries. In 2004, Disney revived its interest in wholly owned international networks and announced the launch of ABC1, a free-to-air channel owned by the ABC Group, targeted specifically for the United Kingdom audience. Regrettably, on September 8, 2007, Disney announced the discontinuation of ABC1 due to its inability to attract a sustainable viewership. Consequently, the company's efforts to develop ABC International were also terminated when ABC1 closed its operations in October of the same year.

However, with the increasing importance placed on national sovereignty, many governments, including those in Japan and Latin America, felt compelled to implement stricter regulations. paragraphs.context: As a media executive, Leonard Goldenson recognized the potential for international expansion of the ABC television network in the 1950s. Inspired by the success of United Paramount Theatres, he sought to adopt similar strategies in the broadcasting industry. ABC's first foray into international broadcasting came with the coverage of the coronation of Queen Elizabeth II in June 1953. Interestingly, both CBS and NBC encountered setbacks, with CBS facing technical problems and NBC experiencing flight delays that hindered their live coverage of the historic event. This presented an opportunity for ABC to shine and gain valuable insights into the Latin American region, as NBC's plane had to make an unscheduled landing there. This unplanned detour opened Goldenson's eyes to the potential of subsidiaries in Latin America, leading ABC to invest in the market by acquiring a majority interest in a Central American network. Recognizing the growing interest in Japan, Goldenson also made strategic investments there, acquiring a 5% stake in two emerging domestic networks - the Mainichi Broadcasting System in 1951 and Nihon Educational Television in 1957. Not content with these achievements, Goldenson expanded ABC's broadcasting properties to Beirut in the mid-1960s, further establishing the network's presence in diverse regions across the world.

paragraphs.context: As of autumn 1949, ABC found itself in a rather precarious position, being regarded as an outsider in comparison to its fierce competitors, CBS and NBC. Despite maintaining equal standing in some major cities, ABC faced a challenge due to a lack of coverage, which was prevalent in a televisual landscape dominated by the aforementioned giants. However, ABC did enjoy a slight advantage over the DuMont Television Network, its third rival during that period. It is worth noting that the television industry was still in its infancy, with only 108 existing television stations across the United States prior to the freeze being lifted in 1952. A reasonable example of this limited coverage can be seen in major cities like Boston, where there were merely two television stations. Similarly, cities such as Pittsburgh and St. Louis could only rely on a single station for their television needs, while other areas like Denver and Portland were yet to experience the introduction of television services. Consequently, this peculiar phase witnessed a notable dichotomy between the flourishing television industry in certain regions and the continued dominance of network radio for entertainment and news broadcasting in others.

paragraphs.context: In 1951, Leonard Goldenson, the president of UPT, approached Noble with a proposal. This proposal involved UPT acquiring ABC, as part of their efforts to diversify. Noble received offers from other parties, including William S. Paley, the founder of CBS. However, merging with CBS would have required them to sell their New York City and Los Angeles stations, among other things. Eventually, Goldenson and Noble reached a tentative agreement in the late spring of 1951. According to this agreement, UPT would acquire ABC and make it a subsidiary, allowing it to maintain its autonomy in management. This tentative agreement was officially approved by UPT's board of directors on June 6, 1951. However, to finalize the transaction, it needed to be approved by the FCC. This was due to the presence of television networks and the recent separation between Paramount and UPT. Since Paramount Pictures was already a shareholder in the DuMont Television Network, the FCC conducted a series of hearings to verify if Paramount was truly independent from United Paramount Theatres and whether any antitrust laws were being violated.

paragraphs.context: In 1952, the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) announced the end of the freeze on new station license applications, and this brought up an important decision regarding the approval of the UPT-ABC merger. One of the FCC Commissioners saw great potential in ABC, with funding from UPT, to establish itself as a strong and competitive third television network. On February 9, 1953, the FCC granted approval for UPT to acquire ABC by offering $25 million in shares. After the merger, the combined company was renamed American Broadcasting-Paramount Theatres, Inc., and its headquarters were located in the Paramount Building at 1501 Broadway in Manhattan. The company held ownership of six AM and several FM radio stations, five television stations, and an impressive 644 cinemas spread across 300 cities in the United States. To comply with FCC regulations that prohibited the common ownership of two television stations in the same market, UPT sold its Chicago television station, WBKB-TV, to CBS for $6 million, subsequently changing its call letters to WBBM-TV. However, ABC's existing Chicago station, WENR-TV, was retained by the merged company. The newly merged company also acquired the WBKB call letters for channel 7, which later became WLS-TV. To finance the development of the new television network, Goldenson, the company's leader, began selling off some of the older theaters.

Additionally, plans were underway to construct a transmitter on Mount Wilson. These developments were in anticipation of the launch of KECA-TV, which had initially been scheduled to commence operations on August 1. paragraphs.context: As an ABC Network Executive, in 1998, we decided to revamp our visual identity with a minimalist approach. We collaborated with the talented design firm Pittard Sullivan to create a simple yet impactful logo - the iconic "ABC Circle" logo on a vibrant yellow background. To enhance our brand image, we launched the "We Love TV" campaign that year, which resonated well with the viewers, becoming synonymous with our network. To create a memorable audio signature, we introduced a new four-note theme tune that perfectly complemented the campaign and became an integral part of our identity. Just like NBC's chimes, CBS' soundmarks, and the Fox Fanfare, our four-note signature provided a recognizable sound that audiences associated with ABC. Over the years, we made periodic updates to the signature for each television season, but certain versions of it continued to feature during the production company vanity cards shown after the closing credits of most programs. However, in the fall of 2015, we decided to part ways with our beloved 1998-2002 four-note jingles for promotions and production company vanity cards. Instead, we opted for a fresh and adventurous music style, while still incorporating the drums from the network's familiar four-note signature at the end. Despite the change, the old four-note theme tune still plays at the beginning of our ABC shows, reminding viewers of our long-standing tradition. Additionally, we continue to use it for ABC on Demand, maintaining a sense of nostalgia and familiarity for our dedicated audience. At ABC, we love TV and strive to create an engaging viewing experience that stays true to our rich history while embracing new and exciting elements.

paragraphs.context:
On July 31, 1995, The Walt Disney Company made a public announcement about their decision to merge with Capital Cities/ABC for a staggering $19 billion. This merger was officially approved by Disney shareholders during a special conference held in New York City on January 4, 1996, and the acquisition of Capital Cities/ABC was successfully completed on February 9. As a result of this acquisition, Disney went on to rename its newly acquired subsidiary as ABC Inc.

Apart from adding the ABC network to its portfolio, the Disney acquisition also led to the integration of ABC's ten owned-and-operated television stations, 21 radio stations, 80% ownership in ESPN, and ownership interests in The History Channel, A&E Television Networks, and Lifetime Entertainment. Additionally, Disney acquired the magazine and newspaper properties that were previously owned by Capital Cities/ABC. However, due to FCC ownership rules, Disney had to sell its ownership of both ABC Inc. and KABC-TV. Resultantly, the independent station KCAL-TV was sold to Young Broadcasting for a total of $387 million.

On April 4,  Disney went on to sell the four newspapers that ABC had controlled under Capital Cities to Knight Ridder for a significant sum of $1.65 billion. This transaction aimed to comply with regulatory requirements and maintain a healthy media landscape.

Following the successful merger, Thomas S. Murphy, the former president and CEO of ABC, departed from the company, making way for Robert Iger to assume the position as the new president and CEO of ABC Inc. Meanwhile, Disney's television production units had already been actively producing series for the network, such as the highly popular Home Improvement and Boy Meets World. Furthermore, the merger provided ABC with access to Disney's extensive children's programming library, which greatly enhanced their Saturday morning programming block.

In 1998, ABC premiered Sports Night, a sitcom created by Aaron Sorkin. The show revolved around the behind-the-scenes challenges faced by the staff of a sports news program similar to SportsCenter. Despite receiving critical acclaim and multiple Emmy Awards, the series unfortunately faced cancellation after two seasons in 2000.

paragraphs.context: On May 1, 1953, WJZ, WJZ-FM, and WJZ-TV, which were the flagship stations of ABC in New York City, decided to change their callsigns to WABC, WABC-FM, and WABC-TV. They also relocated their operations to 7 West 66th Street, just one block away from Central Park. This move was made to establish a more centralized and convenient location for broadcasting. paragraphs.context: In response to the growing concern over the dominance of major networks in the broadcast landscape, the FCC took a significant step in 1970 by implementing the Financial Interest and Syndication Rules. They decided to divide their operations into two distinct entities: Worldvision Enterprises and ABC Circle Films. Worldvision Enterprises, an established company, focused on producing and distributing programming for U.S. syndication, while ABC Circle Films served as a dedicated production unit. This strategic split enabled ABC to comply with the new regulations and ensure fair competition in the industry. Worldvision Enterprises was eventually acquired by a consortium of ABC executives for an impressive sum of nearly $10 million.

As a TV network executive, I am proud of our achievements during the 1976–77 season. We introduced some new and successful shows that resonated with the audience. In January, we premiered Roots, a miniseries based on the acclaimed novel by Alex Haley, which had been published the previous year. It was a groundbreaking production that captivated viewers and went on to become one of the highest-rated programs in American television history, concluding with a remarkable finale.

During September, we launched The Love Boat, a comedy-drama anthology series created by the talented Aaron Spelling. This unique show, revolving around the crew and passengers of a cruise ship with three intertwined stories, faced initial criticism but surprised everyone by becoming a ratings triumph. It sailed smoothly for nine incredible seasons, entertaining audiences and solidifying our network's position at the top.

On September 13, 1977, we took another bold step by airing Soap, a controversial soap opera parody that pushed boundaries. It was not afraid to tackle unconventional themes and introduced the first openly gay main character portrayed by the incredibly talented Billy Crystal, who was then an unknown actor. Although its journey on our network concluded on April 20, 1981, Soap made a lasting impact and added diversity to our programming.

Overall, the success of Roots, Happy Days, The Love Boat, and Soap, alongside other outstanding shows, allowed our network to secure the number one spot in the ratings for the first time during the 1976–77 season. Our dedication to delivering quality entertainment has paid off, and we continue to strive for excellence in the television industry.

paragraphs.context: The evolution of the ABC logo has witnessed several significant transformations since the network's establishment back in 1943. paragraphs.context: In the year 1965, our corporate entity, American Broadcasting-Paramount Theatres, underwent a name change and became the American Broadcasting Companies. As the ABC Marketing Manager, I worked closely with design agency LoyalKaspar to introduce a revised version of the ABC logo for the 2013-14 season. We officially unveiled the updated logo on-air on June 17, following its preview during our upfront presentation on May 14. Our goal was to give ABC a fresh identity while staying true to the original design by Paul Rand.

The new logo features a simpler gloss design and lettering that closely resembles Rand's original circle logo. The gold version is primarily used on entertainment-oriented outlets like ABC.com, WATCH ABC, and ABC Studios. For ABC News, we opted for steel blue and dark grey versions. paragraphs.context:
In 1954, major television networks in the United States saw a significant boost in their advertising revenues. ABC experienced a 67% increase, earning a total of $26 million. NBC's revenue went up by 30%, reaching $100 million, while CBS witnessed a 44% rise, with a total of $117 million. Despite this, the number of primary affiliates differed greatly between the networks. CBS had the majority of its programs carried by 74 affiliates, while NBC had 71 primarily affiliated stations. ABC, on the other hand, only had 14 primary affiliates.

This discrepancy was mainly due to the size of the markets. In most cases, smaller markets lacked the capacity to support three full-time network affiliates. Occasionally, in markets where a third full-time affiliate was feasible, the only available commercial allocation was on the less-desirable UHF band. It was worth noting that the All-Channel Receiver Act, which required UHF tuning, was not passed by Congress until 1961. This meant that viewers had to purchase a converter to access UHF stations before this mandate. Even with a converter, the signal quality was often marginal at best. Furthermore, during the analog television era, UHF stations faced challenges in rugged terrain, resulting in inadequate reception.

With these factors in play, many potential station owners hesitated to invest in a UHF station, particularly if they had to affiliate with a weaker network.

qas.question: How many primary affiliates did ABC have in 1954?
How many primary affiliates did CBS have in 1954?
What important legislation was passed by Congress for the television industry in 1961?
The All-Channel Receiver Act mandated the support of what kind of tuning?

paragraphs.context:
As a TV industry analyst, I have observed that except in major markets, ABC often had to settle for a secondary position on one or both of the existing stations. This was usually achieved through airing its programming during off-hours. However, there was one exception to this trend in the 1980s: WKST-TV in Youngstown, Ohio (now WYTV), which managed to maintain a strong viewership despite its smaller market size and its proximity to the larger cities of Cleveland and Pittsburgh, even before Youngstown's economic decline.

According to Goldenson, this situation meant that ABC's shows had approximately five times fewer viewers compared to its competitors. Despite generating less viewership, ABC still had decent financial resources during that time, allowing the network to increase its content production. However, ABC's limited coverage continued to hamper its growth over the next two decades. It wasn't until the 1960s that several smaller markets grew large enough to support a full-time ABC affiliate. In fact, some very small markets had to wait until the 1980s or even the introduction of digital television in the 2000s to have access to ABC programming. This technology enabled stations like WTRF-TV in Wheeling, West Virginia to broadcast ABC shows on a digital subchannel, even though they had been airing the network's programs at non-traditional time slots for decades prior to that.

paragraphs.context: In April 1959, Desilu Productions, the company I work for, successfully launched their highly anticipated detective series, The Untouchables. This was a significant achievement for our team as we faced initial rejection from CBS due to their concerns about the level of violence depicted in the show. However, our persistence paid off when we pitched the series to ABC, who recognized its potential and agreed to pick it up. It's worth noting that violence was a contentious topic in the television industry at the time, as networks like ABC were cautious about its portrayal. Nonetheless, Desilu Productions took a bold stance, pushing boundaries and reaping the rewards of our innovative approach. Looking back, it's impressive to see that in January 1959, when the show first hit the airwaves, it quickly gained immense popularity. So, it's safe to say that our decision to collaborate with ABC and challenge the status quo in terms of the portrayal of violence paid off handsomely. All in all, The Untouchables marked a significant milestone for Desilu Productions, showcasing both our ability to adapt to the evolving demands of television viewers and our dedication to delivering compelling content.

As a legal advisor for the United States Department of Justice, I had concerns regarding the proposed merger between ABC and ITT. On December 20, 1966, I, Donald F. Turner, expressed doubts about the potential impact of this merger on the emerging cable television market, as well as the potential influence of ITT's overseas ownership on the journalistic integrity of ABC. Despite ITT management's assurance of maintaining ABC's autonomy in the publishing business, I believed that further investigations were necessary.

Consequently, the Department of Justice filed a complaint in July 1967, leading to ITT facing trial in October 1967. It was only after the trial's conclusion on January 1, 1968, that the merger was formally canceled to ensure the preservation of fair competition and protect the interest of the public.

paragraphs.context: In December 1984, Thomas S. Murphy, the chief executive officer of Capital Cities Communications, reached out to Leonard Goldenson to discuss a potential merger between their companies. On March 16, 1985, ABC's executive committee approved the merger offer, which was officially announced on March 18, 1985. Capital Cities acquired ABC and its affiliated properties for a sum of $3.5 billion, paying $118 for each of ABC's shares. Additionally, they provided a guarantee of 10% (equivalent to $3) per share, totaling $121 per share. To finance the acquisition, Capital Cities secured a loan of $2.1 billion from a consortium of banks. In order to comply with FCC ownership regulations, Capital Cities sold certain assets that they were unable to keep, generating $900 million. They also divested several cable television systems, which were purchased by The Washington Post Company and later became Cable One. Warren Buffett's company, Berkshire Hathaway, loaned the remaining $500 million. As part of the deal, Warren Buffett committed to buying $3 million worth of shares at a price of $172.50 per share. Despite complying with the new FCC ownership rules, which allowed broadcasters to own a maximum of 12 television stations, ABC and Capital Cities decided to sell WXYZ-TV and Tampa independent station WFTS-TV to the E. W. Scripps Company. This decision was made due to an FCC prohibition on same-market ownership of television and radio stations by a single company. It is worth noting that initially Capital Cities/ABC intended to pursue a cross-ownership waiver in order to retain WXYZ and Capital Cities-owned radio stations WJR and WHYT.

paragraphs.context: As a television network executive, we believed in the strategy of counterprogramming against our competitors. Our goal was to create a distinct and appealing image for ABC by offering a lineup of programs that stood out from what was being shown on other networks. This approach allowed us to strike a balance between film and television, thanks to our successful western series and action-packed shows like Zorro. By pitting them against NBC and CBS' variety shows in the fall of 1957 and later challenging their detective shows in 1959, we emerged victorious. To attract our audience, we strategically scheduled our 66-minute series to start half an hour before our competitors' hour-long shows. However, our dedication to entertainment drew criticism in May 1961 when Life magazine expressed concern over the overwhelming public support and sponsorship for these types of shows, leading to a decline in quality news programming. They even referred to it as an unofficial law that was "replacing the good programs with the bad ones".

paragraphs.context: In May 2013, ABC introduced a new streaming service called "WATCH ABC," which was a reimagined version of their existing streaming platform on ABC.com and a mobile app for smartphones and tablets. This service allowed viewers to watch full-length episodes of ABC shows and also provided live streams of local ABC affiliates in select markets, making it the first offering of its kind by a U.S. broadcast network. The concept was inspired by the success of WatchESPN, a similar streaming service offered by ABC's sister network ESPN. However, the live streams of ABC stations were only accessible to authenticated subscribers of participating pay television providers in certain markets. The initial rollout of this service included New York City O&O WABC-TV and Philadelphia O&O WPVI-TV, who were the first stations to offer live streams of their programming through WATCH ABC. They even provided a free preview of the service for non-subscribers until June 2013. By the start of the 2013-2014 season, the remaining six ABC O&Os also began offering live streams of their programming through WATCH ABC. Additionally, Hearst Television, a media company that owns several ABC affiliates, including stations in Boston, Kansas City, Milwaukee, and West Palm Beach, also reached an agreement to provide live streams of their programming on the WATCH ABC service.

paragraphs.context: In the television broadcasting industry, it is quite intriguing to observe how certain networks have affiliates serving the same market but operated by different owners. One such example can be found in Tampa, Florida, where WFTS-TV and WWSB independently serve the area. This situation also arises in Grand Rapids, Michigan, with WZZM and WOTV as separately owned and operated affiliates. Similarly, in Kansas City, Missouri, we see this unique scenario between KMBC-TV and KQTV, which is licensed in St. Joseph, Missouri, but considered a separate market according to Nielsen despite their close proximity. Moreover, WWSB and WOTV are affiliates that cater to regions where the main ABC station's signal is insufficient. This can be traced back to the time before 1994, when WTSP served as Tampa's primary ABC affiliate. WWSB was established in order to fulfill the need for a southern coverage area, including Sarasota, as WTSP's transmitter had to be adjusted to evade interference with Miami's WPLG, another ABC affiliate broadcasting on VHF channel 10, just like WTSP.

paragraphs.context: A notable figure known as Genghis Khan rose to power through the unification of various nomadic tribes in Northeast Asia. After establishing the mighty Mongol Empire and being acclaimed as "Genghis Khan," he initiated a series of invasions known as the Mongol invasions, which led to the conquest of vast regions across Eurasia. These conquests encompassed both raids and invasions of significant dynasties such as Qara Khitai, Caucasus, Khwarezmid Empire, Western Xia, and Jin. Notably, these military campaigns were often accompanied by the brutal extermination of civilian populations, particularly in the territories controlled by the Khwarezmian and Xia rulers. By the time Genghis Khan's life came to an end, the Mongol Empire had gained control over a substantial portion of both Central Asia and China.

paragraphs.context: Before his death in 1227, Genghis Khan designated Ögedei Khan as his successor and divided his empire into khanates among his sons and grandsons. Unfortunately, the exact location of his burial site in Mongolia remains a mystery, as it is an unmarked grave somewhere in the vast expanse of the country. Genghis Khan's descendants, driven by ambition and conquest, expanded the Mongol Empire across a significant portion of Eurasia. They conquered and incorporated territories comprising present-day China, Korea, the Caucasus, Central Asia, and extensive parts of Eastern Europe, Russia, and Southwest Asia. The brutality and large-scale slaughters during these conquests gave rise to the fearsome reputation that Genghis Khan and his empire hold in local histories.

paragraphs.context: Temüjin, who would later become the great leader known as Genghis Khan, was most likely born in 1162 in Delüün Boldog, a region near the Burkhan Khaldun mountain and the Onon and Kherlen rivers in northern Mongolia. This area is not far from the present-day capital, Ulaanbaatar. The Secret History of the Mongols recounts that Temüjin was born clutching a blood clot, a traditional omen indicating his future as a remarkable leader. He was the second eldest son of Yesügei, a prominent Khamag Mongol chief who belonged to the Kiyad tribe and was an ally of Toghrul Khan from the Keraite tribe. Temüjin's mother, Hoelun, gave birth to him as her first-born. According to the Secret History, Temüjin received his name in honor of Temüjin-üge, a Tatar chieftain who had recently been captured by his father.

Chilaun, who later became one of Genghis Khan's generals, played a crucial role in his escape. Temüjin cleverly hid himself in a river crevice, managing to slip away from the yurt where he was held captive, under the cover of darkness.
